column2: This paper investigates the chemical etching mechanism of conducting interpenetrating polymer networks (C-IPNs) based on poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) during a reactive ion etching (RIE) process. The study reveals a synergetic degradation mechanism where oxygenated radicals released from the polymer network enhance the etching of PEDOT. The research demonstrates high etching rates for C-IPNs due to this mechanism, allowing for efficient microfabrication of electrochemical devices. The paper also explores the successful application of this etching process in fabricating PEDOT-based microactuators.

The paper discusses the development of highly conformable conducting polymer electrodes for in vivo recordings, specifically targeting applications in electrocorticography (ECoG). The electrodes are made using PEDOT:PSS due to its high conductivity and biocompatibility, integrated onto a flexible parylene substrate. These electrodes are designed to conform to the brain's surface, offering less invasiveness compared to traditional silicon probes. The study demonstrates that these electrodes can effectively record biological signals and outperform gold electrodes in similar configurations.

This paper presents the development of transparent microelectrode arrays (MEAs) made from PEDOT:PSS, enabling simultaneous electrophysiology and advanced optical microscopy. The electrodes exhibit low impedance and high transparency, allowing for artefact-free recordings and compatibility with techniques like calcium imaging and super-resolution microscopy. These MEAs demonstrate high signal-to-noise ratios and maintain performance under laser illumination, supporting both electrophysiology and optical imaging capabilities.

This research paper presents the development of flexible microelectrocorticography (μECoG) arrays using PEDOT:PSS electrodes for simultaneous electrophysiology and MRI. The study demonstrates that these arrays are compatible with ultra-high magnetic field MRI up to 9.4 T and provide high-resolution neural recordings from the cortical surface of rodents. The PEDOT:PSS μECoG arrays minimize imaging artefacts and allow for multimodal brain monitoring, integrating electrophysiology with MRI. This approach offers insights into brain function by combining high spatial and temporal resolution with large-scale imaging capabilities.

The paper presents a novel fabrication process for microelectrode arrays (MEAs) using conducting polymers, specifically PEDOT:PSS, with parylene-C as the insulating layer. This method is versatile and avoids harsh chemical or ion etching, making it compatible with sensitive materials. The resulting MEAs demonstrate low impedance and high signal quality for electrophysiological recording, validated by successful recordings from rat hippocampus slices. The approach offers a cost-effective and flexible alternative to traditional metal-based MEAs, with potential applications in neuroscience and pharmacology.
